Expectation1: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation1: A bride-to-be and her entourage arrive early, visibly anxious about the tight wedding schedule.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: The coordinator emailed a brief suggestion about organizing supplies a different way if time allows.
Story: I was just finishing up sweeping the salon floor when the door chimed and a bride-to-be swept in, her friends trailing behind her. Their faces were tense, eyes darting to the clock. I knew my job—smile, welcome them, make them feel at ease. “Congratulations!” I said, ushering them to their seats, trying to project calm. But as I reached for my apron, my phone buzzed with an email from the volunteer coordinator at the shelter. She’d suggested reorganizing the supply closet today if I had a spare moment, and I’d promised to help after my shift. I could picture the cluttered shelves, the way she’d looked at me last week, hopeful I’d take initiative. Now, with the bridal party needing every ounce of my attention and the coordinator counting on me, I felt the pressure mounting. I wanted to be present for these women, to make their day special, but I also didn’t want to let down the team at the shelter. My mind raced, torn between the expectations of both worlds, unsure how I could possibly meet them all.
